abstract: pmc BMC Public Health BMC Public Health 63 bmcph BMC Public Health 1471-2458 BMC PMC12487170 PMC12487170.1 12487170 12487170 41029623 10.1186/s12889-025-24534-x 24534 1 Research Relationship between biological ageing, premature mortality, life expectancy, and number of live births: a prospective cohort study of the UK women Guo Huanyu 1 Liu Yuqing 1 Yang Ruiming 2 Li Xuebing 1 Teng Yubing 1 Wei Wei 102594@hrbmu.edu.cn 2 3 4 Zhang Dandan dandanzhang@hrbmu.edu.cn 1 1 https://ror.org/05vy2sc54 grid.412596.d 0000 0004 1797 9737 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The First Affiliated Hospital of Harbin Medical University, 2 https://ror.org/05jscf583 grid.410736.7 0000 0001 2204 9268 Department of Nutrition and Food Hygiene, School of Public Health, Key Laboratory of Precision nutrition and health, Ministry of Education, Harbin Medical University, 3 https://ror.org/05jscf583 grid.410736.7 0000 0001 2204 9268 Department of Pharmacology, College of Pharmacy Key Laboratory of Cardiovascular Research, Ministry of Education, Harbin Medical University, 4 https://ror.org/05jscf583 grid.410736.7 0000 0001 2204 9268 National Key Discipline, School of Public Health, Department of Nutrition and Food Hygiene, Harbin Medical University, 30 9 2025 2025 25 478168 3239 23 5 2024 20 8 2025 30 09 2025 02 10 2025 02 10 2025 ¬© The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Objective There are varying perspectives on the impact of the number of live births on health, and few studies have explored whether the number of live births is associated with female aging. Given the global impact of age-related diseases and premature death, this study aimed to evaluate the associations of the number of live births with the biological ageing, premature mortality and life expectancy of women. Methods A total of 272,494 participants from the UK Biobank who completed the questionnaire on the number of Live births between 2006 and 2010 at baseline were enrolled. Participants were categorized into 6 groups based on the number of live births, and participants with one live birth composed the reference group. A general linear regression model and Cox proportional hazards model were used to evaluate the associations of the number of live births with biological ageing and premature mortality in women. A restricted cubic spline (RCS) was used to visualize the dose‚Äíresponse relationship. Moreover, the latest Office for National Statistics life tables were used to calculate life expectancy. Results During a median follow-up of 12.7 years, 10,992 cases of all-cause premature death were documented. After adjustment for potential confounders, compared to women who had one live birth, women who had no live births had a greater risk of premature death (hazard ratio, HR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.17, 95% CI: 1.09‚Äì1.25), whereas women with two or three live births had a lower risk of premature death (HR‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.88, 95% CI: 0.83‚Äì0.93, HR‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.88, 95% CI: 0.83‚Äì0.95), which showed a U-shaped relationship ( P P Conclusions There was a U-shaped relationship between the number of live births and the biological ageing, premature mortality and life expectancy of women. Women who had no live births or five or more live births were more likely to experience accelerated biological ageing, with a higher risk of premature death and a lower life expectancy. Based on these evidence, it is recommended that healthcare providers focus on guiding women towards a balanced reproductive strategy that optimizes both health outcomes and longevity. Some studies have proposed that childbirth may reduce the risk of breast cancer, uterine cancer, and ovarian cancer by influencing hormone levels and the expression of specific genomic traits [ 1 2 3 Biological aging refers to the irreversible natural changes in the metabolic and physical characteristics of cells as individuals age, leading to impaired self-regulation and regeneration capabilities, changes in the structure and function of tissues and organs, and an increased risk of age-related diseases [ 4 5 6 9 Furthermore, the results from observational studies regarding the potential link between the number of live births and women‚Äôs risk of mortality are inconsistent [ 10 13 14 15 16 14 15 17 18 19 20 24 To fill this knowledge gap, this study utilized data from the UK Biobank (UKB) to assess the associations between the number of live births and the biological ageing, premature all-cause mortality, and life expectancy of women. Moreover, to perform an accurate evaluation, extensive confounders, including socioeconomic factors, lifestyle factors and biological factors, were adjusted for. This study provides novel insights into the relationships between the number of live births and the biological ageing, premature all-cause mortality, and life expectancy of women for clinical and public health reference for the first time and will be useful for the development of future interventions. Materials and methods Study population A brief overview of the UKB study design is provided below, as the study design and methods have been reported elsewhere in detail previously [ 25 26 n n n Exposure assessment The number of live births is a useful indicator of reproductive history. To determine the number of live births, participants were asked ‚ÄòHow many children have you given birth to? (Please include live births only)‚Äô in a touch-screen questionnaire completed at baseline (2006‚Äì2010). Due to small number of women with the highest parity, we pooled data from women with five or more live births. In accordance with previous studies [ 14 27 28 Ascertainment of premature mortality and biological ageing Death information and the date of death were confirmed by reference to the death certificates held by the NHS Information Centre for participants from England and Wales and the NHS Central Register Scotland for participants from Scotland. The participants were considered to have premature mortality if their deaths occurred at an age younger than 75 years [ 29 30 Biological ageing was measured from different perspectives, including the frailty index (FI), ŒîKDM-biological age and homeostatic disorder (HD). The FI, ŒîKDM-biological age and HD were previously constructed and validated in the UKB [ 31 32 Covariates We also controlled for a series of confounders in all models, including age (years), race (white, mixed, Asian or Asian British, black or black British, Chinese or other ethnic group), Townsend Deprivation Index (TDI), qualifications (college or university degree, A levels/AS levels or equivalent, O levels/General Certificate of Secondary Education (GCSE) or equivalent, Certificate of Secondary Education (CSE) or equivalent, National Vocational Qualification (NVQ), Higher National Diploma (HND), Higher National Certificate (HNC) or equivalent, other professional qualifications, e.g., nursing, teaching; responses options of none of the above or prefer not to answer), body mass index (BMI), smoking status (never, past and current), alcohol consumption status (never, past and current), metabolic equivalent task (MET) minutes per week for moderate activity (minutes), MET minutes per week for vigorous activity (minutes), summed MET minutes per week for all activities (total MET minutes per week for all activities, including walking, moderate and vigorous activity), histories of diseases (diabetes, hypertension, asthma, emphysema and chronic bronchitis), and female-specific factors (use of oral contraceptive pills, history of stillbirth, spontaneous miscarriage or termination, menarche). The TDI is a composite measure of deprivation based on unemployment, non-car ownership, non-home ownership, and household overcrowding. A greater TDI implies a greater degree of deprivation. Details of the assessment of covariates are described in the Supplementary material. Statistical analysis The baseline characteristics, in terms of demographics, lifestyle factors, health conditions and female-specific factors, are presented as the mean (standard deviation, SD) and number (percentage). General linear models and a chi-square test were used to compare the differences in baseline characteristics according to the number of live births. To examine the associations between the number of live births and ageing-related markers and premature death due to all causes and to provide more information on this issue, we calculated the FI, ŒîKDM-biological age (Œî‚Äâ=‚Äâchronological age minus KDM-biological age) and HD based on previous studies. The participants were divided into six groups based on the number of live births (none, one, two, three, four or 5 or more), and general linear models were generated to determine the differences in the FI, ŒîKDM-biological age and HD among the groups, with adjustment for potential covariates. Furthermore, we used women with one live birth as the reference group, and the relationship between the number of live births and premature all-cause death was evaluated using Cox proportional hazards regression (CPH) models. The survival time was reported as months between the baseline UKB survey and the death or census date (1 February 2022). A series of CPH models were developed. Model 1 was a crude model without adjustment for covariates, and the other four CPH models were adjusted for potential covariates, including four aspects‚Äîdemographic characteristics (Model 2), lifestyle habits (Model 3), disease status at the time of the baseline survey (Model 4), and female-specific factors (Model 5)‚Äîto evaluate whether the different covariates influenced the number of live births and the risk of premature all-cause death in women. Additionally, we performed a restricted cubic spline (RCS) analysis to visualize the survival relationship between the number of live births and the risk of premature all-cause death in women after adjustment for these covariates. The covariates in the general linear regression, CPH and RCS models were identified based on previous studies, and a directed acyclic graph was constructed to identify the final covariates. We tested the proportional risk hypothesis using Schoenfeld residual to ensure the validity of the model hypothesis (Supplementary Fig.¬†2). Furthermore, we plotted a correlation coefficient heatmap between continuous variables and premature mortality (Supplementary Fig.¬†3) to test the linearity assumption. Details of these are described in the Supplementary material. To test the potential association between the number of live births and the risk of premature all-cause mortality, we evaluated interactions by incorporating multiplicative interaction terms of the number of live births and age, race, BMI, TDI, alcohol drinker status, smoking status, history of diagnosed diabetes, hypertension, asthma, emphysema and chronic bronchitis in the CPH models. If the multiplicative interaction terms were statistically significant, we performed a stratified analysis to provide more detailed information on the associations between these covariates. To transform the results of the CPH models to more direct knowledge of the health impacts of the number of live births on life expectancy, we calculated the life expectancy by the number of live births. Life expectancy is a statistical concept that refers to the average number of years a group or individual is expected to live, based on the current mortality rates at specific ages, within a defined period. This estimation is derived from Life Table, which provide detailed data on age-specific mortality rates. Life expectancy is a comprehensive health indicator that reflects exposures during both acute and life-course stages [ 33 34 37 30 38 ùëó ùëó ùëó ùëó Several sensitivity analyses were performed. In the first analysis, participants whose follow-up duration was less than 1 or 2 years were excluded to determine whether severe illness affected the results, as the impact of the number of live births on premature death and biological ageing is long term, and shorter follow-up times (less than one or two years) due to serious illnesses could influence the relationships between the number of live births and premature death and biological ageing. The second analysis involved additional adjustments for dietary factors (including fresh fruit intake, dried fruit intake, oily fish intake, salt added to food, cereal intake, processed meat intake, and mineral and other dietary supplements intake) to examine whether dietary factors had an effect on the relationship. The third analysis involved further adjustment for biochemical indicators (including albumin, triglyceride, glucose, low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, and total bilirubin levels) to remove the impact of certain biochemical indicators unrelated to reproduction on outcomes. The fourth sensitivity analysis excluded participants under the age of 50 to eliminate the potential impact of women who had not completed childbearing on the study results. The fifth sensitivity analysis excluding women with pregnancy outcomes such as stillbirth, spontaneous abortion, or pregnancy termination, including women with a history of stillbirth, spontaneous abortion or termination of pregnancy, wowen that do not konw and prefer not to answer, in order to investigate whether these pregnancy outcomes could introduce bias into the findings. The sixth sensitivity analysis used participants‚Äô birth dates as the starting time of the study to account for potential confounding effects related to age. However, since birth dates are considered sensitive personal information, the data was not aggregated. Instead, we compiled the participants‚Äô birth year and month to estimate their approximate birth dates. Seventh, to eliminate the potential influence of the reference group selection, we conducted two additional sensitivity analyses, using the groups with 0 Live births and 2 live births as the reference groups, respectively. Since the average total fertility rate (TFR) in the sample was 1.8, we chose the closest value, the mode, which corresponds to participants with two live births, as the reference group for analysis. Additionally, comparing individuals with no childbirth experience to those who have given birth in terms of biological aging, premature mortality, and life expectancy provides valuable insights. Therefore, we also analyzed participants with zero live births as the reference group. All the statistical analyses were conducted with R 4.2.2, and p values‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.05 were considered to indicate statistical significance. We found that both nulliparous women and women with more than five live births had a greater risk of premature mortality, which showed a nonlinear trend for the association between the number of live births and the risk of premature mortality. Similarly, the RCS also showed a U-shaped relationship (P for nonlinearity‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.001), which further supports the findings of the CPH models, as shown in Supplementary Fig.¬†4. The nadir for premature all-cause death risk was estimated from the RCS to be two live births, which was significantly lower than one live birth. Additionally, the all-cause premature mortality risk of women with three or four live births was lower than that of women with one live birth. Moreover, women without any live births had a significantly greater risk of premature all-cause death than women with one live birth. Although the data for women with five or more live births were not significant, there was a clear upwards trend in the RCS curve. Additionally, we found a similar relationship between the number of children and premature all-cause mortality among men and among women. Compared with men with one child, men with two, three or four children had lower risks of premature all-cause mortality (HR 2 3 4 0 Sensitivity analyses did not affect the assessment of the relationship between the number of live births and all-cause premature mortality risk (Supplementary Table 2). Similar results were observed after excluding participants with less than 1 and 2 years of follow-up, respectively. To avoid the possible influence of biochemical indicators on the results, we repeated our analyses by adjusting for biochemical indicators. The results barely changed. The results after further adjusting for covariates and dietary factors remained almost the same. Additionally, the sensitivity analysis, which included only women older than 50 years at enrollment, showed no significant change, as shown in Supplementary Table 3. The sensitivity analysis, excluding women with stillbirths, spontaneous miscarriages, or terminations, yielded similar results. Consistent with previous findings, women with zero live births had the highest rate of premature mortality, while those with two or three live births had a lower rate of premature mortality compared to those with one live birth (Supplementary Table 4). Although the confidence interval for women with four live births showed a marginally non-significant association, it still suggested a clear protective trend. In addition, the results of the sensitivity analysis, using participants‚Äô date of birth as the study‚Äôs starting time to calculate the number of follow-up years, as presented in the Supplementary Table 5, reveal similar findings. Moreover, we conducted two supplementary sensitivity analyses, using the zero Live births group and the two Live births group as reference groups, respectively. The results indicated that the choice of reference group did not alter the assessment of the relationship between the number of live births and all-cause premature mortality, as detailed in Supplementary Tables 6 and 7. We found that, when using zero live births as the reference group, women with a history of childbirth had a significantly lower risk of all-cause premature mortality, with the lowest risk observed among those who had given live birth twice, a value significantly lower than for those with only one live birth. When using the two live births group as the reference group, both zero and one live birth remained significantly associated with a higher risk of all-cause premature mortality. However, no statistically significant association was found between having more than two live births (including three, four, five or more) and the risk of all-cause premature mortality. This may be because women with more than two live births lose the protective effect against premature mortality observed in those with exactly two live births. The ‚ÄúHigher‚Äù indicator on the upper axis corresponds to increased life expectancy in women with varying live birth parity relative to the reference group, whereas the ‚ÄúLower‚Äù annotation on the lower axis signifies reduced life expectancy in these parity-specific cohorts Association between the number of live births and biological ageing The estimated values of the FI, ŒîKDM-biological age and HD for each live birth group after multiple covariate corrections calculated using a general linear model are presented in a box plot in Fig. 2 for trend  Fig. 2 Frailty index, ‚ñ≥KDM-biological age, homeostatic disorder (HD) adjusted for multiple covariates. Adjusted covariates included age, race, qualifications, Townsend deprivation index (TDI), BMI, alcohol drinker status, smoke status, MET minutes per week for moderate activity, MET minutes per week for vigorous activity, summed MET minutes per week for all activity; history of diabetes, hypertension, asthma, emphysema and chronic bronchitis, use of oral contraceptive pills, history of stillbirth, spontaneous miscarriage or termination, age when periods started (menarche) at baseline Discussion In this prospective study of 272,494 participants from the UKB, we found that compared with women who had only one live birth, women who had no live births were associated with a greater risk of premature all-cause mortality and a lower life expectancy, whereas those with two, three, or four live births were associated with a lower risk of premature all-cause mortality and a greater life expectancy. These associations were independent of biological factors, lifestyle habits, socioeconomic status, and preexisting diseases. Similarly, this study revealed a relationship between the number of live births and premature all-cause mortality via sensitivity analyses, demonstrating the robustness of the results. Moreover, compared with those of women with one live birth, the estimated values of the FI, ŒîKDM-biological age and HD adjusted for multiple covariates in women with two or three live births were lower, and the corresponding values in women with five or more live births were greater. Our results on premature mortality are consistent with results reported in Sweden [ 14 17 The findings of the subgroup analyses suggested that the association between the number of live births and the risk of all-cause premature mortality differed among different races, which may be attributed to the relatively small sample sizes of the mixed group and other ethnic groups. In addition to genetic factors influencing racial differences in different countries, socioeconomic-environmental factors also play an important role in these differences. Studies have shown that there are racial differences in fertility patterns [ 39 40 41 39 40 41 42 43 42 43 In addition, our study provides novel evidence of the relationship between the number of live births and mortality risk. Our results on premature cause-specific mortality indicate that the risk of premature all-cause mortality associated with a greater number of live births could be partly attributed to premature CVD-specific and cancer-specific mortality. These observations are consistent with previous evidence linking the number of live births with various conditions, including CVDs [ 44 45 46 47 48 49 50 51 53 53 54 55 1 2 For the first time, we reported that women who had no Live births were more Likely to have a 1.40-year lower Life expectancy at age 40 years (95% CI: 0.77‚Äì2.00), and women with two, three or four Live births had a 1.13- (95% CI: 0.64‚Äì1.64), 1.13- (95% CI: 0.45‚Äì1.64), and 0.93-year (95% CI: 0.09‚Äì1.85) higher life expectancy, respectively, than participants with one live birth. Moreover, we found that accelerated biological ageing and functional decline were potential influencing factors, as the estimated values of the FI, ŒîKDM-biological age and HD after adjustment for multiple covariates exhibited significant changes. Our research is similar to the changes in HD caused by the number of live births in previous articles, giving rise to a U-shaped overall relationship between the number of live births and biological ageing [ 56 57 58 45 59 60 61 3 62 64 65 65 19 The present findings may have several public health implications. First, the evidence is complementary to that on the association between the number of live births and all-cause mortality and fills the gap in the understanding of the relationships between the number of live births and all-cause premature mortality, life expectancy, and biological aging. Second, the evidence provides a better understanding of the number of live births needed to maximize women‚Äôs health benefits. The number of live births is easily assessed in clinical and public settings, and recommendations on behavioural changes regarding pregnancy or contraception for women in need are provided. Our findings could help guide and improve the development of strategies and practices for women‚Äôs health. Although our study has several advantages, including a large sample size, extensive covariate adjustment, and consistent results in several sensitivity and subgroup analyses, several potential limitations should be carefully considered. First, we cannot exclude the possibility that a high number of live births is a marker for a lower socioeconomic level. However, subgroup analyses indicated that the positive association between the number of live births and the risk of mortality was consistent across the socioeconomic subgroup groups. Second, in this study, we determined the number of live births by asking ‚ÄúHow many children have you given birth to? (Please include live births only)‚Äù. Because this question did not include the number of stillbirths, spontaneous miscarriages or terminations that women may have had, we could not obtain specific data associated with these situations. As described earlier, if the number of live births affects long-term health conditions, the number of stillbirths, spontaneous miscarriages or terminations will also be an important source of information. Further studies including these basic facts are needed to investigate the effects of the number of stillbirths, spontaneous miscarriages or terminations on long-term health. Third, although we controlled for many socioeconomic factors and lifestyle factors, we lacked explicit information on marital status, age at first birth, attitudes and values, and early life circumstances that may be associated with both fertility and health. Therefore, we could not exclude single women and those who never experienced pregnancy. These unadjusted covariates may affect the relationship between the number of live births and premature all-cause death. Fourth, our study was only performed in the UK population, and these results may not be generalizable to populations in other regions [ 25 Conclusions In conclusion, our study revealed relationships between the number of live births and the risk of premature all-cause mortality, life expectancy, and biological ageing in women. Smoking and alcohol consumption may affect the association between the number of live births and premature all-cause mortality. Further clinical trials are warranted to validate these findings.
